Hi Colin,

> The central issue here is how we define fitness. I think the t=
he root
> of your logical error is in considering fitness as a simple metri=
c
> where we can take any two organisms/agents and state that one is
> fitt=
er than the other based on reproductive efficiency and overall
> population=
 size. I believe this view of fitness as a simple linear
> metric is wrong =
and thus any conclusions we build from this assumption
> are on shaky groun=
d.
> 

Agreeing on an exact definition of biological fitness may be difficu=
lt, especially as there isn't a complete consensus even among biologists (e=
.g. Dawkins lists many different definitions in "Extended Phenotype" ch. 10=
). But whether "Survive and Reproduce" is an objective rests not on an exac=
t definition of biological fitness, but in the disparity between fitness dy=
namics in nature and the way that EC traditionally abstracts fitness as an =
objective -- which *is* typically a simple metric that compares any two ind=
ividuals on a linear scale. 

I completely agree that blindly optimizing th=
is sort of measure is simplistic and not equivalent with what nature does! =
However, this is the traditional approach in EC and is typically what we me=
an by objectives, not only in EC but in machine learning as a whole. 

Whil=
e natural evolution does optimize reproductive efficiency locally within ni=
ches, it does not do so globally. That is, bacteria do not preclude bears. =
However, in traditional EC, bacteria would preclude bears, because bacteria=
 are a simpler, more efficient solution to the problem of survive-and-repro=
duce, were survive-and-reproduce the objective. 

So, while we abstract nat=
ural evolution as optimizing an objective in EC and in general look only at=
 the absolute high-fitness individuals, in nature more inefficient solution=
s are still interesting. I maintain that solutions to reproduction such as =
humans are analogous to incredibly inefficient pole-balancers that are reco=
gnized as interesting in their own right and still investigated within the =
search process.

I think if there was an objective in natural evolution, ra=
ther than survive-and-reproduce, it might be "survive-and-reproduce competi=
tively within your niche or find a new way to live." But this isn't an obje=
ctive in the traditional sense either, because it is relative not only to t=
he niche an organism exists within, but also to what niches exist already. =
In contrast, typical objectives in EC or machine learning are "find a neura=
l net that maximizes how far this biped robot walks before it falls" or "fi=
nd parameters that minimize the classification error." These define specifi=
c points in the search space that might count as solutions.

Basically, I b=
elieve we are in agreement over most things but perhaps disagreeing only in=
 definitions? That is, we agree that natural evolution is more nuanced than=
 the simple treatment of fitness functions in traditional EC, but may disag=
ree on particular definitions of biological fitness or objectives.
